h:head.h:title: OSCE GNM_2nd Year _Changing iv solution container and tubing

select1.label: Goal: The patient experiences minimal to no trauma when solution and tubing are changed Identify the patient. Ask the patient if he/she is allergic to any medication, iodine, or tape, as appropriate.

Gather all equipment and bring to the bedside. Check the IV solution and medication additives against the physician's order. Label the IV if medication is added. Include the date, time, and your name or initials.
Explain the procedure and reason for change to the patient.
Perform hand hygiene.
To Change IV Solution Container
Carefully remove protective cover from new IV solution container and expose the bag entry site.
Close the clamp on the IV tubing. If using an electronic device, turn the device to the "hold" position.
Lift the container off the IV pole and invert it. Quickly remove the spike from the old IV container, being careful not to contaminate it.
Steady the new container and insert the spike. Hang on the IV pole.

Reopen the clamp, check the drip chamber of the administration set on the tubing, and adjust the flow. Readjust the electronic device by turning the device "ON" and verify the programmed flow rate. Inspect for air bubbles in the tubing. If using an electronic device, check that the device is operating correctly.
Label the container according to agency policy. Record on the intake and output record and document on the chart according to agency policy. Discard used equipment properly. Perform hand hygiene.
To Change IV Solution Container and Tubing
Prepare the IV solution and tubing, checking the IV order with the physician's order and labeling the IV with the date, time, and name or initials.
Maintain strict aseptic technique when opening sterile packages and the IV solution.
Clamp the IV tubing, uncap the spike on the administration set and insert into the entry site on the IV bag or bottle as the manufacturer directs.
Squeeze the drip chamber and allow it to fill at least halfway.

Remove the cap at end of the IV tubing and while maintaining its sterility, open the IV tubing clamp, and allow fluid to move through the tubing. Allow fluid to flow until all air bubbles have disappeared and the entire length of the tubing is primed (filled) with IV solution. Close the clamp and recap the end of the tubing, maintaining sterility of the setup.
If an electronic device is to be used, follow the manufacturer's instructions for inserting the tubing and setting the infusion rate.
Label the tubing with the date and time that tubing was hung.
Place time-tape on the container and hang the IV on the pole.
Close the clamp on the existing IV tubing. Also, close the clamp on the short extension tubing connected to the IV catheter in the patient's arm.
Remove the current infusion tubing from the resealable cap on the short extension IV tubing. Using an antimicrobial wipe, swab the resealable cap and insert the new IV tubing into the cap.
Open the clamp on the IV tubing and on the short extension tubing. Check the IV flow. Readjust the electronic device as needed.
Regulate the IV flow according to the physician's order.

Label the IV tubing with the date, time, and your initials. Label the IV solution container and record the procedure according to agency policy. Discard used equipment properly and perform hand hygiene.
Record the patient's response to the IV infusion.
